hypotheses: Younger people perceive higher risk of COVID-19 infection than older people.
Problem-focused coping strategies are more prevalent than emotion-focused ones.
claim.statement: Older people estimate the risk of COVID-19 as being less than younger people. Coping strategies are highly problem-focused.

data.source: Quantitative online survey using an online access panel
data.notes: Online-representative sample regarding gender, age, and federal states distribution.

method.description: A quantitative online survey was conducted with questions focusing on risk perception, coping strategies, and emergency food preparedness related to COVID-19.
steps: Design survey instrument focused on risk perception, coping strategies, and food preparedness.
Recruit participants using an ISO-certified online panel provider.
Collect data from 1300 respondents over 5 days.
Clean data to retain 1242 valid responses.
Analyze results focusing on gender, age, and geographical differences.
method.outcome_variable: Risk perception and coping strategy preference related to COVID-19

results.summary: Older people estimate the risk of COVID-19 as being less than younger people. Coping strategies are predominantly problem-focused. Respondents store food mainly due to convenience and preparation for quarantine.

numerical_results.outcome_name: Risk perception of infection for family

metadata.original_paper_title: COVID-19: Risk perception and Coping strategies. Results from a survey in Germany.
